metadata.title: Trochanteric Bursitis
anatomical location body part affected: Upper lateral thigh or hip area/trochanteric bursa (as well as the more proximal subgluteusmedius/minimus bursa),iliotibial band
description: Trochanteric bursitis is a common extraarticular musculoskeletal pain syndrome and a leading cause of hip problems presenting in primary care, with an incidence of 1.8 cases per 1,000 persons per year(1)

In chronic cases, the underlying pathology may not be an inflammatory process, contrary to the term bursitis. Also, soft tissues (e.g., tendons of the gluteus medius and minimus, fascia latae) may be involved in addition to the trochanteric bursa(1)
Lateral thigh pain in trochanteric bursitis can negatively impact ADLs, including general mobility, walking, and sleeping on the affected side, as well as quality of life(1)

Nonoperative treatment that includes activity modification, physical therapy (e.g., stretching of the iliotibial band [ITB] and hip rotator muscles, strengthening the hip abductors, postural correction, pelvic core stabilization), and corticosteroid injection is effective in most cases, whereas surgery is indicated for refractory cases(1,6) ICD-10  codes
M70.72 other bursitis left hip (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

ICD-10 codes.M70.72: other bursitis left hip (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified. Reimbursement will depend on patient’s insurance coverage
presentation signs and symptoms: Aching and point tenderness in the upper lateral thigh are the chief complaints, noted especially when pressure is applied (e.g., lying on the affected side)(1)
In acute cases, pain can be focal, sharp, and intense, with signs of inflammation (e.g., swelling, redness) at the greater trochanter(1,6)
In chronic cases, pain is usually dull and diffuse, may radiate down the lateral leg, and does not extend past the knee, simulating radicular conditions such as sciatica or piriformis syndrome(1)

Symptoms can disturb sleep and general mobility/gait, more so when the condition is bilateral. Painful activities include prolonged standing, squatting, and the first steps after rising from a chair(1)
Pain increases with active hip flexion and external rotation, as in sitting with affected leg crossed over opposite knee(1) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Patients might be at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies
Perform specific assessments for trochanteric bursitis after first screening for hip joint and lumbosacral dysfunction
Swelling, redness, and warmth are unusual in chronic cases and indicate other ongoing pathology

causes: The primary mechanism of injury in acute cases without direct trauma/injury is excessive friction or compression ofoverlying tissues on the trochanteric bursa
Chronic cases may involve enthesopathy of tendons that connect to the greater trochanter(11)
Irritation of the trochanteric bursa likely worsens with shortening/tightening of the ITB and associated fascia(1)

The high prevalence of trochanteric bursitis in women with wide hips and adults with generalized ITB tenderness or knee/hip osteoarthritis suggests that altered lower limbbiomechanics may be a contributing factor(1,8)
pathogenesis: Histologic changes in acute bursitis include synovial inflammation, hypertrophy of the bursal wall, and fibrous adhesions
Degenerative changes due to attrition of the fasciae latae on the trochanteric enthesis may be the underlying pathology inchronic cases(1)

Enthesopathy of the gluteus medius or minimus (e.g., gluteus mediustendinopathy) can mimic and /or cause trochantericbursitis. IT band and gluteusmedius increased tendon compression secondary to a Trendelenburg gait may cause pain overthe inflamed bursa(11)
10–25%  of all persons with lateral hip pain have a diagnosis of greater trochanteric pain syndrome (GTPS),which may ormay not include trochanteric bursitis(1)
The pathogenesis of generalized tenderness in the ITB is unclear, but may involve myofascial trigger points

Researchers in the United Kingdom tested the hypothesis that there is no inflammatory component to trochanteric bursitisin a prospective, case-controlled,  blinded study that involved 25 patients who met criteria for trochanteric bursitis and amatched control group of 25 patients. All patients were recruited from a cohort of patients undergoing primary total hiparthroplasty(3)–During surgery a biopsy of bursal tissue was harvested and the gluteus medius and minimus tendons and their insertionswere inspected. Signs of thickening, thinning, and macroscopic tears were documented. Routine hip arthroscopy was thenperformed–Not one of the 50 samples showed histological evidence of acute or chronic inflammation–The authors concluded that the true pathogenesis of greater trochanteric pain syndrome is complex and not fullyunderstood
risk factors: Four times more frequent in females than males
Osteoarthritis in the hip or knee
Running (especially uphill) and regular use of stairs or step machines for exercise
True or functional leg-length  discrepancies (short side more often symptomatic)

overall contraindications precautions: Unusual findings suggestive of coexisting pathology that call for thorough evaluation and perhaps consultation include the following: An observable pelvic, hip, or knee deformity Swelling, redness, or warmth around the hip A palpable mass in the thigh A capsular pattern of restricted hip ROM  Lumbar or sacroiliac dysfunction Groin pain that radiates to the hip joint Knee pain
Frequent painful snapping of the affected hip requires diagnostic imaging to rule out intraarticular pathology such as torn labrum, subluxation, or ligamentumteres tear
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Patients might be at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies
Perform specific assessments for trochanteric bursitis after first screening for hip joint and lumbosacral dysfunction
Swelling, redness, and warmth are unusual in chronic cases and indicate other ongoing pathology

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Patients often report the gradual onset of ache and tenderness in the lateral thigh area, without morning stiffness or discomfort at rest. Ask about any recent trauma, back pain, or neurological symptoms in thigh, or “snapping” in hip

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management The vast majority of patients are treated conservatively, with surgery considered only in recalcitrant cases. The following conservative interventions may be implemented(1,6) Prescription of NSAIDs Recommendations for activity modificationstretching of the ITB and hip rotator muscles, hip abductor strengthening, postural correction, pelvic core stabilization; capsular mobilization of the hip Corticosteroid injection (if initial steps are unsuccessful in relieving symptoms)(1,6) Dry needling(9) Extracorporeal shock wave therapy (ESWT)(10) Examples of surgical techniques that may be implemented Open or arthroscopic bursectomy(1) Arthroscopic bursectomy or debridement of gluteal tendons and bursa, in conjunction with iliotibial band release(6)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: The diagnosis is most often made clinically; however, imaging with ultrasonography,

arthrography, or MRI is occasionally required to exclude other causes. Xrays  are usually negative but indicated to evaluate painful hip joint or calcific tendinitis. Laboratory tests are performed if an infectious(1,4) or rheumatologic(1) process is suspected
Gluteus medius tendon pathology on MRI is seen on both symptomatic and 88% of asymptomatic women according to researchers in Australia(8)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Painful activities may include prolonged standing, squatting, and the first steps after rising from a chair. Pain may increase with active hip flexion and external rotation, as in crossing affected leg over the other while sitting. Pain is usually associated with certain daily activities such as walking up incline or climbing stairs. Patient might also complain of pain with pressure to that area (e.g., lying on the affected side)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms. Condition may be bilateral. Pain may be located in the upper lateral thigh and may radiate down to or below the knee
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). The chief complaint is aching in the upper lateral thigh. If acute onset, pain can be focal, sharp, and intense. However, pain in chronic hip bursitis is usually dull and diffuse and may radiate down to or below the knee, simulating radicular conditions.(1) Tenderness is noted with direct pressure, such as when lying on the affected hip
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Lying on affected hip may disturb sleep
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)Document the use of any supplemental oxygen Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _______________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Has there been prior trauma to the involved hip? Ask about treatment for any hip disease. Any lumbar spine or sacroiliac problem? Any knee problems?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, obesity, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Has physical activity recently changed or increased? Did symptoms begin after unaccustomed physical activity? Are current symptoms limiting patient’s ability to participate in activities he or she enjoys?Document the use of any assistive or adaptive equipment that is used at home or work
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Determine height, weight, and BMI. Is patient overweight or obese?
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess need for (and proper fit of) crutches, cane, or walker, if applicable, for protected ambulation
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess pedal pulsesAssess sensation in the distribution of the femoral nerve
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Assess general mobility and transfers (sit to stand and getting onto examination table). Observe for antalgic gait
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess for antalgic gait, specifically Trendelenburg gait. In severe cases with disturbed gait, use of a cane may help unload the affected lower extremity and decrease pain at lateral hipAssess hip joint mobility using Patrick’s test, hip flexion, abduction, and external rotation (FABER). Groin pain on Patrick’s test suggests hip joint pathology. SI joint pathology is localized to SI joint. Lateral hip pain may suggest trochanteric bursitis
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Scan functional strength of the lower extremities. Assess strength of the hip abductors and rotators using manual muscle testing (MMT)
observation inspection palpation includi: Swelling, redness, and warmth are typical in acute cases but unusual in chronic cases

Palpate for adhesions in gluteus medius and minimus tendons. The hallmark test is exquisite tenderness on deep palpation over and superior to the greater trochanter(1) -If the patient has tenderness in the mid-trochanter region, the trochanteric bursa is likely involved, whereas tenderness in the superior trochanter region indicates the subgluteusmedius bursa may be involved(1) •Pain:  Assess for increased pain with resisted hip abduction and external rotation. Screen for referred hip pain using straight-leg  raise and for sacroiliac joint tenderness. Pain in the proximal anterior thigh or groin suggests possible involvement of the associated lumbar nerve roots and/or hip joint pathology
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess for leg-length  discrepancy (distance from anterior superior iliac spine [ASIS] to femoral condyle for thigh length and from femoral condyle to medial malleolus for lower leg length). Observe for any postural abnormalities in standing, such as hip internal rotation and/or hip flexion. Assess for pelvic asymmetry and/or SI joint dysfunction(6)
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess hip and knee ROM. To rule out hip osteoarthritis, check for restriction in active and passive internal hip rotation and end-range  flexion. Patient may complain of lateral hip pain with active internal and external rotation at 45 degrees of hip flexion with bursitis(1)Evaluate any reported disability in ADLs, such as squatting, putting on socks, and climbing steps
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosispatient lies on unaffected side with knee and hip flexed; affected leg held by examiner in hip abduction, hip extension, and knee flexion. Positive test if affected leg remains abducted upon release (tightness). Reproduction of patient’s lateral hip pain when hip is adducted to exam table(6)patient stands on affected leg and attempts to elevate unaffected leg. Positive if gluteal crease of unaffected leg remains level or dropswith patient supine, the hip is flexed, abducted and externally rotated. While stabilizing the opposite side of the pelvis, an external rotation, abduction and posteriorly directed force is then applied to the knee of the bent leg. A positive test reproduces the patient's pain(1,6) -Researchers in the United States found that subjects with greater trochanteric pain syndrome are more likely to have a positive FABER on the unaffected side than subjects with other lumbopelvic pain or healthy controls(5)19 with greater trochanteric pain syndrome, 33 with lumbopelvic pain, and 27 healthy controls

contraindications precautions: Hypertension  cold can lead to an increase in blood pressure
Avoid aggressive treatment with cold modalities over an acute wound
Avoid placement over superficial nerves for extended periods (> 1 hour)
Cold may be counterproductive if being used to facilitate muscle relaxation and reduce pain in patients who do not tolerate the modality

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Trochanteric bursitis with possible enthesopathy/lateral thigh pain that interferes with or restricts ADLs, gait, and mobility Rule out  (1,6) Hamstring or abductor strain; tears of the hip abductors Femoral stress fracture Acetabular labral disease Neuritis Iliopsoas, piriformis, gluteus medius, and gluteus minimustendinopathy Calcific tendinitis at gluteus mediustendon(7) Referred hip pain from pelvic, intra-abdominal,  or retroperitoneal disease, or lumbar spine disorders DVT in groin or thigh Avascular necrosis Femoral neck fracture (even with negative X-ray)  if the patient has sustained hip trauma or presents with significant pain, marked limitation of motion, or unwillingness to bear weight Hip joint disease (e.g., hip osteoarthritis, slipped capital femoral epiphysis) Lumbosacral radiculopathy
prognosis: Patients usually respond well to conservative treatment if the causative or predisposing factor can be successfully addressed(6) –Correction of mechanical problem;e.g., leg-length discrepancy –Weight loss if obesity may be the cause –Modify training schedule if overuse is the cause –Stretching if poor flexibility of the hip rotators is an issue –Strengthening of core gluteals and hip muscles, especially eccentrically, if weak
treatment summary: Prospective, controlled trials of nonoperative interventions for trochanteric bursitis are lacking

Current expert opinion for physical therapy treatment includes protection in the acute phase (use of ambulatory aid if necessary), foot orthotics, pain management (ice, NSAIDs), activity modification (e.g., avoidance of walking or running uphill)

Strengthening should focus on the core, hip abductors, extensors, and external rotators and should include eccentric loading of the gluteal muscles if tendinopathy is also suspected. Focus stretching for ITB and hip rotators(1,6)
Evidence is lacking to support the use of therapeutic ultrasound, including iontophoresis or phonophoresis, for treatment of trochanteric bursitis
Coexisting lower limb osteoarthritis, postural dysfunction, gait abnormalities that stress the hip should also receive intervention
In recalcitrant cases, an ultrasound-guided  corticosteroid injection into the bursal area may be effective(1,6)

Dry needling is an effective alternative to cortisone injection for trochanteric bursitis, based on an RCT conducted in the United States(9) –Forty-three  participants (50 hips) were randomly assigned to either the cortisone injection or dry needling group –Outcomes measured at 1,3, and 5 weeks were pain (V AS 1–10) and the Patient-Specific  Functional Scale (0–10) –Patients in both groups experienced decreased pain and improved ability to perform daily activities –Researchers concluded that cortisone injections did not provide reduction in functional limitations or greater pain relief than dry needling –With similar outcomes, patients may choose dry needling as a low-risk  treatment, when compared to a cortisone injection

ESWT for the treatment of trochanteric bursitis showed beneficial effects in pain relief over a 24-month  period(10) –Based on research in the United Kingdom –Data was collected through the ASSERT (Assessment of the Effectiveness of Extracorporeal Shock Wave Therapy for Soft Tissue Injuries) database on 40 participants at baseline, 3, 6, 12, and 24 months following ESWT treatment  –Pain perception (V AS), Lower Extremity Functional Scale (LEFS), and 6 scores of the EuroQol-5D  quality of life instrument were utilized to evaluate the participants . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Pain and tenderness in the lateral thigh that disturbs sleepand ADLsResolve/decrease pain and improve quality of movement as well as sleepHip protection _ Restrict ambulation on inclines or stairs. Consider ambulating with cane on unaffected side to reduce irritation of trochanteric bursa _ _ Prescription, application of devices and equipment _ Customized foot orthotics _ _ Physical agents/ mechanical modalities _ Ice pack/ice massage or heat pack for pain management _ _ No evidence to support use of phonophoresis, iontophoresis, or low-intensity pulsed ultrasound _N/A Patient education for pain management (ice pack and heat pack), independent exercise program, and hip protection Reduced ROM and strength at hipNormalize strength and ROM of hipTherapeutic exercises _ Progressive, multidirectional hip strengthening and flexibility program. Place special emphasis on stretching ITB and hip internal and external rotators, as well as on strengthening the hip abductorsManual therapy _ If treating for gluteus mediustendinopathy, manually mobilize gluteus medius tendon and follow with assisted stretching of hip abductorsHip abductor strengthening program with appropriate elastic resistance band. Patients with very weak hip abductors can begin strengthening in prone position(2)  Inflexible/tight ITB; hip rotators, and hip flexorsReduce contracture of ITB and improve flexibility of hip rotators and flexorsTherapeutic exercises _ Stretch ITB and hip internal and external rotators and hip flexorsProgress as indicated and appropriate for each unique patientOber’s exercise for stretching the ITB Altered lower limb and gait mechanicsNormalize gait Therapeutic exercises _ Gait training with appropriate device, if neededProgress based on individual patient needs; consider patient’s age and physical impairmentsInstruct patient in a home exercise program to complement the physical therapy program that should be progressed as tolerated Dysfunctional posture Patient fit with appropriate orthopedic aids (foot orthotics) to correct postural dysfunctionPosture correction _ Posture correction (leg- length discrepancy, hip drop) with application of devices (foot orthotics, heel lift, as indicated) and guided instruction. Patient education in correction of sitting and standing postural habits _N/A N/A .

patient fit with appropriate orthopedic: Return to prior functioning in aggravating activities
patient satisfaction: Level of patient satisfaction with rehabilitation – self report

maintenance or prevention: Maintain strength and flexibility of tissues that support the hip. Continue hip protection strategies
patient education: Orthogate for patients website, trochanteric bursitis of the hip, https://www.orthogate.org/patient-education/hip/trochanteric-bursitis-of-the-hip Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
